page.title: 03Relief & soils of Hordley
page.content: The area is flat or gently undulating with the southern part mostly flat at about 80m.OD.A low ridge runs west and south east from Hordley which rises about 17m. above the flatlands. To the north of the canal the land rises to a height of 148m.just outside our area. Some 16000 years ago the upland zone was the margin of an ice sheet and is part of a terminal moraine belt across North Shropshire.The debris is derived largely from soft red sandstones and gives rise to deep soils that are favourable to farming.To the south the soils are more recent and consist of peats and silts. The silts are linked with the River Perry while the peats were associated with a lake extending down to Ruyton. These peats gave rise to a zone of wetlands at Tetchill Moor and along the Perry valley south of our area.
